title: square type recommendations
content:
Hi,

I’m looking for any recommendations on a well-drawn squarish extended font with “r”s like in Futura.

Thanks for any help.

Cø

 [‹ Well-crafted Jersey Font](http://web.archive.org/web/20081008042457/http:/www.typophile.com/node/42574 "Go to previous forum topic") [H&FJ Italics + indesign = problems ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20081008042457/http:/www.typophile.com/node/42528 "Go to next forum topic")
author: curtis_eberhardt

comments.content:
Futura is known for the round appearance it has, so the question is a bit confusing but here are some recommendations, if I understand the question correctly.

[Trade Gothic Ext](http://web.archive.org/web/20081008042457/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/linotype/trade_gothic_lt_std_bold_extended_ot/?sample_text=rounded)  
 [Helvetica Neue Ext](http://web.archive.org/web/20081008042457/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/linotype/helvetica_neue_lt_pro_bold_extended/?sample_text=rounded)

Do you mean a font which was constructed in a square grid but not necessarily with square geometric shapes? ie the letters fit inside a square but aren’t themselves \*square\*?

-Rafe

Hi,

Sorry, yes, on a square grid and nothing like the full Futura font— just the way the “R” has a straight line coming out of it as opposed to the “R” of helvetica which has a curve in it.

This is an example, but looking for something a little more well drawn but contemporary in feel.

Thanks,  
Ce

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20081008042457im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/square_3842.jpg)

The sample font in your “COLD.” image is Bank Gothic. There are a number of Bank Gothic alternates, some of which offer different vibes. See this list on Identifont – [http://www.identifont.com/find?font=bank+gothic&q=Go](http://web.archive.org/web/20081008042457/http:/www.identifont.com/find?font=bank+gothic&q=Go "http://www.identifont.com/find?font=bank+gothic&q=Go")

Try looking at Hebrew font families.  
I’ll explain with this little list:  
Hebrew lettering is square  
the different languages in a type family must be cohesive  
Therefor, the roman letters in a Hebrew font family should be square.

If an Israeli typographer notices this, please validate or deny this point.
